myopenmath.statement:
For each oriented surface described below, determine whether the flux of \displaystyle\vec{{{F}}}={z}\vec{{{i}}} is positive, negative, or zero.
If the surface \displaystyle{S} is a flat square in the \displaystyle{y}{z}-plane (\displaystyle{0}\leq{y}\leq{2} and \displaystyle{2}\leq{z}\leq{5}) oriented outward (in the positive \displaystyle{x} direction), then the flux of \displaystyle\vec{{{F}}}={z}\vec{{{i}}} through \displaystyle{S} is
Positive
Negative
Zero
If the surface \displaystyle{S} is a flat square in the \displaystyle{y}{z}-plane (\displaystyle-{2}\leq{y}\leq{0} and \displaystyle-{5}\leq{z}\leq-{2}) oriented outward (in the positive \displaystyle{x} direction), then the flux of \displaystyle\vec{{{F}}}={z}\vec{{{i}}} through \displaystyle{S} is
Positive
Negative
Zero
If the surface \displaystyle{S} is a flat square in the \displaystyle{x}{y}-plane (\displaystyle{2}\leq{x}\leq{5} and \displaystyle{2}\leq{y}\leq{5}) oriented downward (in the negative \displaystyle{z} direction), then the flux of \displaystyle\vec{{{F}}}={z}\vec{{{i}}} through \displaystyle{S} is
Positive
Negative
Zero
If the surface \displaystyle{S} is a flat square in the plane \displaystyle{z}={7} (\displaystyle{2}\leq{x}\leq{5} and \displaystyle{2}\leq{y}\leq{5}) oriented downward (in the negative \displaystyle{z} direction), then the flux of \displaystyle\vec{{{F}}}={z}\vec{{{i}}} through \displaystyle{S} is
Positive
Negative
Zero
If the surface \displaystyle{S} is a flat square in the \displaystyle{x}{z}-plane (\displaystyle{2}\leq{x}\leq{5} and \displaystyle{2}\leq{z}\leq{5}) oriented rightward (in the positive \displaystyle{y} direction), then the flux of \displaystyle\vec{{{F}}}={z}\vec{{{i}}} through \displaystyle{S} is
Positive
Negative
Zero
